member.name: M:ModApi.AssetDatabase.GetAssetPath(UnityEngine.Object)
member.summary: Gets the path name relative to the project folder where the asset is stored. All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".
member.param: A reference to the asset for which to get the path.
member.returns: The path name relative to the project folder where the asset is stored.
member.exception: Could not find the 'GetAssetPath' method via reflection for the AssetDatabase.

member.name: M:ModApi.AssetDatabase.GetAssetResourcesPath(UnityEngine.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the path name relative to the resources folder where the asset is stored. If the asset cannot be found in the resources folder, a null is returned.
member.param: A reference to the asset for which to get the path.
If set to true, the file extension will be removed before returning the path.
member.returns: The path name relative to the resources folder where the asset is stored or null if it could not be found.

member.summary: The PID used to tune this PID's gain values.

member.summary: The last error

member.name: M:ModApi.Automation.PidController.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Handler for PID events.

member.name: E:ModApi.Automation.PidController.AutoTuneComplete
member.summary: Occurs when the PID's auto-tune has completed.

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.ErrorAccum
member.summary: Gets the accumulated error (integral) over a given period of time. Used by the integral component to correct for accumulated errors.

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.ErrorMaxAccum
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum accumulatable error (integral) value, or null to not limit the maximum. Note: Setting this to null will attempt to "unwind" all accumulated errors. If, for instance this is used on a helicopter tail and the tail blows out, causing the pid to accumulate 2 full circles of error (very extreme case), the PID will attempt to remove all 2 * 2PI radians...which would not typically be desireable.

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.IsAutoTuning
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this instance is performing an automatic gain tuning operation.
member.value: true if this instance isis performing an automatic gain tuning operation; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.PidGains
member.summary: Gets or sets the PID gain values (x=proportional, y=integral, z=derivative).

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.Value
member.summary: Gets the last output value from the PID system.
member.value: The last output value from the PID system.

member.name: P:ModApi.Automation.PidController.ValueComponents
member.summary: Gets the individual pid value components which make up the final value (x=proportional, y=integral, z=derivative). Used for debugging/tuning the pid.

member.name: M:ModApi.Automation.PidController.Reset
member.summary: Resets any inter-frame PID system values such as those related to errors. The PID system will operate as if it were newly created, yet with the current PID gain values.

member.name: M:ModApi.Automation.PidController.StartAutoTune(System.Single)
member.summary: Starts the automatic tune.
member.param: The gain of the integral to use to auto-tune the pid. The value shouldn't meaningfully impact the outcome, only the time the auto-tune takes to complete.

member.summary: Updates the PID system and returns the value suggested to correct for the supplied error.
member.param: The current value of the item being optimized by the PID controller.
member.returns: The value suggested to correct for the supplied error.

member.name: M:ModApi.Automation.PidController.UpdateAutoTune(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Updates an in-progess gain auto-tune.
member.param: The current value of the item being optimized by the PID controller.
member.returns: The value suggested to correct for the supplied error.

member.summary: Calculates the PID output given the supplied inputs.
member.returns: The individual PID value components...should be added together to get the final value.

member.name: T:ModApi.Common.Events.EventMigrator`1
member.summary: Class to facilitate subscribing to a "migrating" event. Example use-case: "As a gizmo, I want to subscribe to a parts's 's event." Normally this is a big pain because you are subscribing to a specific command pod's events instead of the idea of "this part's craft nodes's active command pod". The active command pod may change, and the part may also be moved to another craft/node entirely. In this case you'd setup migration triggers for and , which will automatically rewire the events when either of those triggers occur to keep subscribers getting notified properly.
member.typeparam: The class type which contains the migrating event to be tracked.

member.name: F:ModApi.Common.Events.EventMigrator`1._actionOnMigration
member.summary: The (optional) action to perform when an even migration occurs.

member.summary: The action to get the object on which the event resides.

member.summary: The migration trigger data.

member.summary: The object which containes the event subscribed to.

member.summary: The subscribe

member.summary: The unsubscribe

member.summary: The handler data

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:ModApi.Common.Textures.Screenshots
member.summary: Functionality related to taking screen-shots.

member.name: M:ModApi.Common.Textures.Screenshots.GetScreenShotSampleRect(System.Single)
member.summary: Gets a rect identifying where from the current screen to obtain a screen-shot of the desired aspect ratio. If the aspect ratio is different than the current resolution, some clipping will occur.
member.returns: A rect identifying where from the current screen to obtain a screen-shot of the desired aspect ratio.

member.name: M:ModApi.Common.Textures.Screenshots.TakeScreenShot(UnityEngine.Vector2i,System.Action{UnityEngine.Texture2D})
member.summary: Takes a screen-shot of the screen's current contents. The final image will be at the specified resolution. Cropping will occur if the specified resolution's aspect ratio is different from the current one.
member.param: The final resolution of the screen-shot.
Action to call when the screen-shot has been captured..
member.remarks: screenSampleRect and resolution must have the same aspect ratio, or the final image will be skewed. It does not have to match the current resolution, however.

member.name: M:ModApi.Common.Textures.Screenshots.TakeScreenShot(UnityEngine.Rect,UnityEngine.Vector2i,System.Action{UnityEngine.Texture2D})
member.summary: Takes a screen-shot of the current screen's contents. The final image will consist of whatever is inside the screenSampleRect, and at the specified resolution. Cropping will occur if the specified resolution's aspect ratio is different from the current one.
member.param: The location within the current screen to capture a screen-shot.
The final resolution of the screen-shot.
Action to call when the screen-shot has been captured..
member.remarks: screenSampleRect and resolution must have the same aspect ratio, or the final image will be skewed. It does not have to match the current resolution, however.

member.name: P:ModApi.Craft.BodyJointData.ConnectedBodyNeutralPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the connected body's neutral joint position in coordinates local to , or null if the current position is its neutral position. This value defines the position where the joint tries to bring the connected body back to...ie, the neutral position. It prevent joints from being "welded" into place when they're saved while they're bent, and could also be used to pre-tension joints for use in things like sling-shots.
member.value: The connected body's neutral joint position, local to .
member.remarks: If the value from xml is null, this property will be updated with the current position upon initial joint creation.

member.name: T:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint
member.summary: An attach point where a part can connect to another part.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._allowInvertedConnection
member.summary: A value indicating whether this attach point can connect to another attach point with its normal pointing in the wrong direction. This requieres that the attach point also supports AllowRotation.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._allowRotation
member.summary: A value indicating whether the attach point allows rotation.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._canReceive
member.summary: A value indicating whether this attach point can receive attachments. This will usually be true. An example of an attach point which would be false is the auto-rotating fuselage attach point. That attach point is used to attach the fuselage to other pieces, but we don't want pieces attaching themselves to that point...other pieces attach to the fuselage via its surface attach point.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._canSeek
member.summary: A value indicating whether this attach point can cast rays looking for connections when its part is being moved in the designer. This is usually true, but for surface attach points and in some special cases this can be false.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._connectionType
member.summary: The attach point's connection type, which determines what attach points this attach point can connect to.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._disableJointCollisions
member.summary: A value indicating whether to disable collisions for a physics joint created at this attach point. This only applies if the attach point is not a Fused type. If this flag is different between the two attach points making up a joint, then the physics joint will be created with collisions disabled.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._fuelLine
member.summary: A value indicating whether this attach point can carry fuel. Used when automatically identifying fuel tanks connected to a fuel source modifier.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._ignoreSurfaces
member.summary: A value indicating whether to ignore connections with surface attach points.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._jointType
member.summary: The type of the joint created by this attach point.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._localJointAxis
member.summary: The local joint axis.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._radius
member.summary: The radius, which is used by adaptive fuselage meshes to automatically adapt to the radius of the attach point. If the radius is zero, then the fuselage meshes will not attempt to auto-adapt to this attach point.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._rayCastFromCursor
member.summary: A value indicating whether to cast the ray from the cursor instead of from the attach point. Some parts that auto-rotate are easier to use if the ray cast is from the cursor, such as the fuel tank.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._requiresPhysicsJoint
member.summary: A value indicating whether this attach point requires the physics joint to be on the rigid body containing this part.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._surfaceCollider
member.summary: The surface collider, if one is used for this attach point.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.AttachPoint._tag
member.summary: The attach point's tag.

An example of an attach point which would be false is the auto-rotating fuselage attach point. That attach point is used to attach the fuselage to other pieces, but we don't want pieces attaching themselves to that point...other pieces attach to the fuselage via its surface attach point.

member.summary: This mode will preserve the state of a property if configured to do so. It will not optimize away the XML state if the value is a non-null, non-empty value.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.Attributes.PartModifierPropertyStatePreservationMode.SaveAlways
member.summary: This mode will preserve the state of a property if configured to do so. It will never optimize away the XML state, regardless of value.

member.summary: Enumerates the way a part can respond to a collision.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionResponseType.None
member.summary: The part will not disconnect or explode as a response to a collision.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionResponseType.DisconnectOnly
member.summary: The part cannot explode. It can only disconnect in response to a collision.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionResponseType.Default
member.summary: The part is capable of exploding or disconnecting as a response to a collision.

member.name: T:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionVelocityMode
member.summary: List of modes that determine how a part will look at its collision velocity when calculating if it needs to disconnect or explode.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionVelocityMode.None
member.summary: The part does not consider collision velocity.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionVelocityMode.OmniDirectional
member.summary: The magnitude of the collision velocity will be used, regardless of its direction.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartCollisionVelocityMode.NormalOnly
member.summary: Only the component of the collision velocity that is aligned with the collision normal will be used. For example, a skipping rock with 100m/s lateral velocity and 5m/s vertical velocity will only consider the 5m/s velocity when colliding with the ground.

member.name: T:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartData
member.summary:
A part is a complete object, which is either added or removed as a whole in the designer. This is different from "Modifiers" which may be used to change a Part's behavior. Once constructed, parts are capable of producing XML to fully describe themselves, or a UNITY GameObject to do the same. Typically, it is only used used for IO purposes, such as saving to an xml file, or loading from XML to create an object for design/simulation.
The Part class defines an object in its entirety. If you can construct an Part by any fashion, you should be able to get a GameObject, and use it in simulation mode. Likewise, any Part (GameObject w/a PartScript) should be able to be used to construct a Part and used to generate XML for saving purposes.

member.name: P:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartData.BuoyancyScale
member.summary: Gets the value to scale this part's buoyancy by. A value of 1 would indicate default buoyancy for the volume of this part's collider. A value lower would indicate that the part is porous. Set to zero to disable buoyancy for a part. This is a rolled-up value based on BuoyancyBaseScale and BuoyancyUserScale.
member.value: The value to scale this part's buoyancy by.

member.name: P:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartData.SymmetryMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the symmetry mode for the part. This is not serialized (at least not at the time of this comment) and it is only used in the designer for convenience so the designer doesn't forget what symmetry mode to use for a part if it is pulled of briefly from the craft. This is only set on the root part of the SymmetrySlice. For checking symmetry mode, use PartScript.SymmetrySlice.SymmetryGroup.SymmetryMode

member.name: P:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartData.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets the "tag" value. Tag is not used by the game, but is intended to be used by XML modders, or modders in general to identify parts (i.e tag="Left Elevon") to make testing changes easer.

member.name: M:ModApi.Craft.Parts.PartModifierScript.RecalculateFrameState(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)
member.summary: Called when a modifier should recalulate the reference frame sate (position/velocity) of any special, "unmanaged" game-objects.
member.remarks: Any children of a craft should have their position updated without using the position delta. However, any rigid-body other than the one associated with a will need its velocity updated with the velocity delta. Any gameobject not under a craft should add both the position and velocity deltas to the current value to keep the same relative state. - Caution: This may be called either when the reference frame recenters, rotates, or when the node's orbit position/velocity is manually updated such as while warping. If subscribing to GameViewScript.ReferenceFrameRecentered event, do not also add deltas in response to that or they'll be added in twice.

member.name: M:ModApi.Craft.IBodyScript.SetCollidingWithTerrainThisFrameFlag
member.summary: Sets a flag on the body indicating that some part of it is currently in contact with the ground this frame. Normal colliders should be handled by the BodyScript automatically, but this method can be used for other types of collision elements, such as wheel colliders, that may not trigger OnCollisionStay events. This must be called every frame that the collision element is in contact with the ground.

member.name: P:ModApi.Craft.IBodyWaterPhysics.IsPrecisionModePerPart
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the current precision mode processes individual parts for water physics, or solely at the rigid body level. This is used to allow PartWaterPhysics objects to know if they need to manually forward water related events since their Update method won't be called.
member.value: true if the current precision mode processes individual parts for water physics; otherwise, false to signify it is calculated solely at the rigid body level.

member.summary: The physics precision seting for water.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.PrecisionModeType.NotifyOnly
member.summary: Does the absolute minimum to raise events. No physics are applied.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.PrecisionModeType.Low
member.summary: Will report either 0 or 1 for UnderWaterAmount (either fully submerged, or not at all). Does bare minimum to provide buoyancy.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.PrecisionModeType.Med
member.summary: Same as Low, except will perform a few additional physics operations to stabilize an object on the surface of the water.

member.name: F:ModApi.Craft.PrecisionModeType.High
member.summary: Will calculate a value ranging from 0 to 1 depending on how much the object is submerged.

member.name: M:ModApi.Craft.Propulsion.RocketNozzleType.GetAltitudeCompensation(System.Single)
member.summary: Gets the altitude compensation factor from 0-1, which indicates how much the nozzle compensates for atmospheric pressure. Zero indicates no altitude compensation and nozzle exit pressure is calculated normally. One indicates perfect compensation so that the exit pressure is always equal to the atmospheric pressure. Values in between lerp between chamber pressure and atmospheric pressure by this percentage.
member.returns: The altitude compensation

member.name: P:ModApi.Flight.Sim.IOrbit.ApoapsisDistanceEffective
member.summary: Gets the effective apoapsis distance for this orbit. For elliptical orbits, this will be the same as . For hyperbolic orbits, this will be the value returned when the distance is calculated for . For hyperbolics, the true distance is infinity, but due to precision anything beyond will result in precision issues...things will begin to equate to equal when they should not be, things will begin to fail to converge, etc. Note: This is not a guaranteed "safe" distance...it is still far as hell out, and may run into issues.
member.value: The effective apoapsis distance for this orbit.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether debug is enabled for this orbit. Its just a flag that can be used to spit out debug info for a specific orbit instead of all of 'em.
member.value: true if debug is enabled for this orbit. Its just a flag that can be used to spit out debug info for a specific orbit instead of all of 'em.; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets see for more info.

members.member:
Gets the theoretical ceiling for the true anomaly of this orbit if it is hyperbolic. Hyperbolic orbits have a true anomaly limit that they approach, but never obtain, nor cross since hyperbolic orbits never complete a circle. If the true anomaly is set to this value, the position/velocity/time would go to infinity, so it should be used as a non-inclusive ceiling/limit. For elliptical orbits it will be NaN and should be ignored.
The maximum valid true anomaly for this orbit.
Use for the maximum true anomaly value that this orbit should ever be set to.

The number of seconds to advance the orbit by. Can be negative./// The time that the orbit will reflect after being advanced by the specified time.
true if the periapsis was crossed while advancing the orbit, otherwise false.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonDownIfEnabled
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the input button was activated this frame. This returns false if the input is disabled.
member.returns: true if the input button was activated this frame and the input is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonIfEnabled
member.summary: Gets the state of the input button.
member.returns: true if the input button is active and enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonRepeating
member.summary: Gets the repeating button state of this input button.
member.returns: true when immediately pressed, then false until the input behavior repeat delay has elapsed, then true for a 1-frame duration repeating at the interval of the specified in the InputBehavior assigned to the input button.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonTimePressed
member.summary: Gets the length of time in seconds that the input button has been continuously held down. Returns 0 if the button is not currently pressed.
member.returns: The duration of the button hold.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonUp
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the input button was deactivated this frame.
member.returns: true if the input button was deactivated this frame; false otherwise.

member.name: M:ModApi.Input.IGameInput.GetButtonUpIfEnabled
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the input button was deactivated this frame. This returns false if the input is disabled.
member.returns: true if the input button was deactivated this frame and the input is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: T:ModApi.Ioc.IContext
member.summary: ioc contexts can be any object type (not just IContext). However, it may be helpful to use this interface as a base to identify that a class is intended to be used as an IOC context (see ICraftContext).

member.remarks: To free resources, should be called when the context is no-longer valid.

member.name: T:ModApi.IResourceLoader
member.summary: An interface for a resource manager that is used for the loading of all resources.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.InstantiatePrefab(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the prefab at the specified path and then instantiates and returns it.
member.param: The path of the prefab to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The instantiated prefab at the specified path or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.InstantiatePrefab``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the prefab at the specified path and then instantiates it, returning the specified component.
member.typeparam: The type of the component to return.
member.param: The path of the prefab to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The requested component on the instantiated prefab at the specified path or null if the component could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.Load``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the asset at the specified path.
member.typeparam: The type of the asset to load.
member.param: The path of the asset to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The requested asset or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadAirfoil(System.String)
member.summary: Loads the airfoil with the speficied name.
member.returns: The requested airfoil.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadAll``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads all assets in a folder or file at path in a Resources folder.
member.param: Pathname of the target folder. When using the empty string (i.e., ""), the function will load the entire contents of the Resources folder.
member.returns: The resources in the folder.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadAsync``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the requested resource asynchronously.
member.typeparam: The type of the requested resource.
member.param: The path of the requested resource.
If set to true, an error will be logged if the resource could not be found..
member.returns: A wrapper for Unity's asynchronous resource request.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadAudio(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the audio clip asset at the specified path.
member.param: The path of the asset to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The requested audio clip asset or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadMaterial(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the material at the specified path.
member.param: The path of the material to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The requested material asset or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadPrefab(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the prefab (not instantiated) at the specified path.
member.param: The path of the prefab to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The uninstantiated prefab at the specified path or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.IResourceLoader.LoadScriptableObject``1(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Loads the scriptable object at the specified path and returns it as the requested type.
member.param: The path of the object to load.
If set to true, errors will be logged to the console.
member.returns: The requested object or null if it could not be found or was not of the expected type.

member.summary: Loads the text asset at the specified path.

member.returns: The text requested or null if it could not be found.

member.name: M:ModApi.Math.MathUtils.CheckRayIntersectionWithSphere(UnityEngine.Vector3d,System.Double,UnityEngine.Ray3d)
member.summary: Checks if the ray intersects the sphere. Source (though he does mess things up, I think): http://kylehalladay.com/blog/tutorial/math/2013/12/24/Ray-Sphere-Intersection.html
member.returns: True if there is an intersection.

member.name: M:ModApi.Math.MathUtils.ComputeRotationContributions(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Transform,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Single)
member.summary: Calculates which rotational axes (x=pitch, y=yaw, z=roll) a force at the supplied position and in the given direction would primarily contribute to, relative to the CoM. 1 = max amount, 0 = none.
member.param: The position where the force is applied, in world coordinates.
The normalized force direction, in world coordinates.
Center of mass transform which is positioned at the CoM and aligned with the desired control orientation from the pilot's perspective of: forward=roll, up=yaw, and right=pitch.
If set to true the contribution values will be inverted.
If set to true only the greatest contributing axis will be used.
Threshold which must be achieved to register a contribution for a particular axis. Lower number means contribution will be more easily registered.
member.returns: Vector3 containing -1, 0, or 1 for each axis (x=Pitch, y=Yaw, z=Roll), identifying which control inputs would be primarily contributed to if a force were applied at the given position/direction.

member.name: M:ModApi.Math.MathUtils.ComputeTranslationContributions(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Transform,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Single)
member.summary: Calculates which translational axes (x=right/left, y=up/down, z=forward/back) a force at the supplied position and in the given direction would primarily contribute to, relative to the CoM. 1 = max amount, 0 = none.
member.param: The position where the force is applied, in world coordinates.
The normalized force direction, in world coordinates.

Center of mass transform which is positioned at the CoM and aligned with the desired control orientation from the pilot's perspective of: forward=toward the front of the pilot, up=toward pilot's head, and right=toward the pilot's right.
If set to true the contribution values will be inverted.
If set to true only the greatest contributing axis will be used.
Threshold which must be achieved to register a contribution for a particular axis. Lower number means contribution will be more easily registered.
member.returns: Vector3 containing -1, 0, or 1 for each axis (x=right/left, y=up/down, z=forward/back), identifying which control inputs would be primarily contributed to if a force were applied at the given position/direction.

member.summary: Gets the intersection with radius.

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.DistanceBlendedTexturesConfiguration
member.summary: A class containing configuration information for distance blended textures.

member.summary: The tile level count.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.DistanceBlendedTexturesConfiguration._distanceAdjustment
member.summary: The distance adjustment value that is added to the distance which determines the tiling level. This adjustment is applied after the distance scalar is applied. Example: If the first tiling level lasts until about 100 meters and this adjustment value is -500, then the first tiling level will last until about 600 meters.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.DistanceBlendedTexturesConfiguration._distanceScalar
member.summary: The distance scalar used to adjust the distance at which the levels begin. Doubling this value will cause tiling levels to begin twice as early as normal.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.DistanceBlendedTexturesConfiguration._scaledUvStartLevel
member.summary: The tiling level at which scaled UV coordinates start being used. If this is set to 3, then tiling levels 1, 2 and 3 will use scaled UV coordinates. The remaining tiling levels will used standard UV coordinates.

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier
member.summary: A planet modifier that provides water materials for a planet.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._sharedMaterial
member.summary: The material shared by all water quads on the planet.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._foamColor
member.summary: The foam color. Foam is applied on top of reflection/refraction in very shallow water.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._foamDepth
member.summary: The maximum depth at which foam is applied.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._foamStrength
member.summary: The intensity of the foam (from no foam at zero to 100% foam color at one).

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._planetNormalWeight
member.summary: The weight of the surface normal when adjusting the normals based on the normal maps. The higher the value, the weaker the normal map contribution will be to the overall surface normal.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._transparencyDepth
member.summary: The depth at which the water's transparency fully fades out to opaque.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._transparencyStrength
member.summary: The water's maximum transparency strength at the surface. This is a value from zero (not transparent) to one (fully transparent).

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._tilingConfiguration
member.summary: The tiling configuration for the water textures.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._fresnelBias
member.summary: The minimum fresnel value. The higher this value, the stronger the reflections will be at a given viewing angle.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._normalMapType
member.summary: The normal map approach used for the water. Blended is the highest quality. BlendedFast is the same as Blended but faster due to more work done in the vertex shader, however it results in some visual artifacts.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._reflectionDistortion
member.summary: The reflection distortion value. The higher the value, the more distortion due to reflection.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._reflectionsEnabled
member.summary: A value indicating whether water reflections are enabled.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._reflectionStrength
member.summary: The strength of the reflection in the water's surface.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._refractionDistortion
member.summary: The refraction distortion value. The higher the value, the more distortion due to refraction.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._refractionEnabled
member.summary: A value indicating whether water refraction is enabled.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._transparencyFadeRange
member.summary: The range in meters (beginning at the transparency fade start distance) over which the water's transparency fades out. This value plus the transparency fade start value should be less than the far clip plane of the near camera.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._transparencyFadeStart
member.summary: The distance in meters at which the waters transparency starts fading out to opaque. This value plus the transparency fade range value should be less than the far clip plane of the near camera.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.Material.WaterMaterialModifier._shaderDistanceBlendDataInitialized
member.summary: A value indicating whether the shader distance blend data has been initialized.

member.summary: Subtract the C input from the A input.

member.summary: Subtract the A input from the C input.

member.summary: Multiply the A and B inputs.

member.summary: Multiply the A and C inputs.

member.summary: Divide the A input by the B input.

member.summary: Divide the A input by the C input.

member.summary: Divide the C input by the A input.

member.summary: Raise the A input to the power of the B input.

member.summary: Raise the A input to the power of the C input.

member.summary: Raise the C input to the power of the A input.

member.summary: Take the absolute value of the A input.

member.summary: Take the minimum value between the A and B inputs.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.BasicArithmeticType.Min_AC
member.summary: Take the minimum value between the A and C inputs.

member.summary: Take the maximum value between the A and B inputs.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.BasicArithmeticType.Max_AC
member.summary: Take the maximum value between the A and C inputs.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.BasicArithmeticType.Sign_A
member.summary: Get the sign of the A input (output should be -1 or 1).

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.Biomes.LayeredBiomes
member.summary: A planet vertex data biome pass modifier that takes sets of inputs and converts them into biome strengths. Biome inputs are applied in layers with the higher priority ones taking precedence.

member.summary: The biome layers.

member.summary: The index of the default biome.

member.summary: An enumeration defining the different type of biome layer inputs.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.Biomes.LayeredBiomes.BiomeInputType.SingleBiome
member.summary: The biome input value represents the strength of a single biome from 0% at 0 to 100% at 1.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.Biomes.LayeredBiomes.BiomeInputType.DualBiome_NegativeAndPositive
member.summary: The biome input value represents two biomes. The primary biome strength is represented by values from 0 (0%) to 1 (100%). The other biome strength is represented by values from 0 (0%) to -1 (100%).

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.Biomes.LayeredBiomes.BiomeInputType.DualBiome_PositiveAndRemainder
member.summary: The biome input value represents two biomes. The primary biome strength is represented by values from 0 (0%) to 1 (100%). The other biome strengths is 100% minus the strength of the primary biome.

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.GenerateHeightType
member.summary: The height generation type.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.GenerateHeightType.LerpMinToMax
member.summary: The generated height is a result of linearly interpolating from the minimum height to the maximum height based off the input value.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexData.GenerateHeightType.LerpToFromZero
member.summary: The generated height is a result of linearly interpolating from the minimum height to zero if the input value is negative or linearly interpolating from zero to the maximum height if the input value is positive. This should not be used if the minimum and maximum heights to not span across zero.

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexDataPlanetModifierPassType
member.summary: The vertex data planet modifier pass types.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexDataPlanetModifierPassType.Biome
member.summary: The 'Biome' pass which runs first. This pass is responsible for setting the biome strength values. It may also set any other output data as well. The input position is available in this pass but the normal is not available. This pass is only ran for common modifiers and will not be executed for biome specific modifiers.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexDataPlanetModifierPassType.Height
member.summary: The 'Height' pass which runs second. This pass runs after the 'Biome' pass and is responsible for setting the height value. It may also set any other output data as well other than the biome strength values. The input position is available in this pass but the normal is not available. This pass is ran for common modifiers first and then executed for biome specific modifiers second.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexDataPlanetModifierPassType.HeightFinal
member.summary: The 'HeightFinal' pass which runs third. This pass is just like the Height pass but it runs after it and is useful for common modifiers that need to run after biome specific height pass modifiers. The input position is available in this pass but the normal is not available. This pass is only ran for common modifiers and will not be executed for biome specific modifiers.

member.name: F:ModApi.Planet.Modifiers.VertexDataPlanetModifierPassType.Final
member.summary: The 'Final' pass which runs last. This pass runs after all other passes and is responsible for setting any remaining vertex data that has not been set. It may set any data other than the biome strength values and the height value. The input position and the normal position are both available in this pass. This pass is ran for common modifiers first and then executed for biome specific modifiers second.

member.param: The XML from which to create the solar system data.
The path where external assets are stored for this solar system. Use null if there are no external assets.

member.name: P:ModApi.Planet.SubBiomeData.SlopeRange
member.summary: Gets the slope range for the biome. Slopes below the min value use the primary data for the sub-biome. Slopes above the max value use the slope data for the sub-biome. Slopes between the min/max value use a blend of both the primary and the slope data for the sub-biome.
member.value: The slope range. Slopes below the min value use the primary data for the sub-biome. Slopes above the max value use the slope data for the sub-biome. Slopes between the min/max value use a blend of both the primary and the slope data for the sub-biome.

member.name: T:ModApi.Planet.TerrainGeneratorDisposed
member.summary: A wrapper for a terrain generator that is going away. The purpose of this class is for it to be hot-swapped during quadsphere disposal to protected background threads from calling native noise methods after they have been disposed (and thus crashing the app). All native noise calls to this terrain generator return dummy data (as do some non-noise calls).

member.summary: An enumeration defining the rag-doll physics quality levels.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.CollidersQuality.Off
member.summary: Collider quality - Off setting.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.CollidersQuality.On
member.summary: Collider quality - Normal setting.

member.name: T:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.DebrisRetentionQuality
member.summary: An enumeration defining the aggressiveness of discarding explosion debris based on their size.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.DebrisRetentionQuality.Low
member.summary: Debris retention - Low setting. Debris are aggressively discarded, including medium and some larger pieces.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.DebrisRetentionQuality.Medium
member.summary: Debris retention - Medium setting. Fewer large debris are discarded, but some medium pieces still are.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.DebrisRetentionQuality.High
member.summary: Debris retention - High setting. Only the smaller debris will be discarded.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.DebrisRetentionQuality.Ultra
member.summary: Debris retention - Ultra setting. Similar to high setting except some parts which would never have debris will have it now.

member.name: T:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.PartFracturingSizeQuality
member.summary: An enumeration defining the size and number of pieces a part's mesh will be fractured into.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.PartFracturingSizeQuality.Off
member.summary: PartFracturing - Off setting. Exploded parts will not fracture into smaller pieces.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.PartFracturingSizeQuality.Large
member.summary: PartFracturing - Large setting. Parts will fracture into fewer, large parts.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.PartFracturingSizeQuality.Medium
member.summary: PartFracturing - Medium setting. Parts will fracture into more, smaller parts.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.PartFracturingSizeQuality.Small
member.summary: PartFracturing - Small setting. Parts will fracture into many, even smaller parts.

member.name: T:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.ParticleEffectQuality
member.summary: An enumeration defining the particle quality levels.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.ParticleEffectQuality.Medium
member.summary: Particle quality - Medium setting. A less taxing particle effect shader

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.ExplosionsQualitySettings.ParticleEffectQuality.High
member.summary: Particle quality - High setting. Higher quality shader that responds to light conditions and have volumetric effects.

member.value: The lifetime in seconds of debris pieces.

member.summary: An enumeration defining the different quality levels for planet cubemaps.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.PlanetCubemapQuality.Low
member.summary: The low quality setting for planet cubemaps. Low resolution textures will be used for distant planets, map view planets, and the main menu planet. Normal mapping will not be used.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.PlanetCubemapQuality.Medium
member.summary: The medium quality setting for planet cubemaps. Low resolution textures and normal maps will be used for distant planets, map view planets, and the main menu planet.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.PlanetCubemapQuality.High
member.summary: The high quality setting for planet cubemaps. Low resolution textures and normal maps will be used for distant planets and map view planets. Higher resolutions textures will be used for the current planet (in flight and map view) as well as on the main menu.

member.summary: An enumeration defining the different texture quality levels for the planet's surface.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.TextureQuality.Off
member.summary: Textures will not be applied to planet surfaces.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.TextureQuality.BlendedFast
member.summary: Use 'fast' distance blended textures. More work is pushed off to the vertex shader at the cost of visual artifacts between blending levels.

member.name: F:ModApi.Settings.TerrainQualitySettings.TextureQuality.Blended
member.summary: Use distance blended textures.

member.name: M:ModApi.Utilities.HasMinimalDifference(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Determines whether the two doubles have a "minimal difference" between them using the specified digits of precision. This is helpful to compare large numbers, which might have very little information after the decimal point, and thus would fail normal CompareDoubles() checks, but are otherwise extremely close with respect to their available digits of precision.
member.returns: true if the two doubles have a "minimal difference" between them using the specified digits of precision; otherwise, false.

member.returns: true if the two Vector3ds have a "minimal difference" between them using the specified digits of precision; otherwise, false.
